authors: April Glover For Daily Mail Australia
description: Radio host and father-of-two slammed a controversial Australian study which claims housewives are a 'drain on the economy' and defended stay-at-home mums on The Today Show.
title: 2GB host Ben Fordham defends stay-at-home mums
title_page: 2GB host Ben Fordham defends stay-at-home mums | Daily Mail Online
text:
Radio host and father-of-two Ben Fordham has slammed a controversial study that blamed stay-at-home mums for being a 'drain on the economy'.
Fordham said on The Today Show that mums shouldn't feel guilty about not rushing back into the workforce.
The 2GB presenter told The Today Show that housewives who look after the children are as important as the men who work to put food on the table.
Ben Fordham has a 15-month-old daughter, Pearl, (pictured) with wife Jodie Speers
The dad-of-two quickly defended housewives and said women shouldn't rush back into the workforce if they are not ready
'To make people feel like they are a drain on the economy for staying at home and looking after the kids that I'm unable to look after because I've got to go to work and earn some money so we can keep living in our house,' he said.
Fordham shares two children - two-year-old Freddy and five-month-old Pearl - with his news presenter wife Jodie Speers who he said 'went quiet' after hearing about the claims.
'Honestly I read it out to my wife and she just went quiet... she doesn't go quiet.'
The famous radio host defended a mother's choice whether to go back to the workforce or not after having children.
'Let’s just have robots running the whole thing, forget the whole idea of parenting': Fordham defended stay-at-home mums on The Today Show
The 2GB host pictured with fellow journalist Peter Stefanovic at his station
He said: 'Do we want an entire generation of children raised completely by childcare? If so, let’s just have robots running the whole thing, forget the whole idea of parenting.'
'There are plenty of parents who like the idea of one of those parents being there as much as they possibly can, or can afford to be, to look after those kids and raise them.'
Social media users supported Fordham's claims that women should not be shamed for staying at home and looking after children, with one Twitter user pointing out the irony that the study was released so close to International Women's Day.
Stay-at-home mothers took to Twitter to support Fordham's claims on The Today Show
One user pointed out the study was released just after the world celebrated International Women's Day
The study singled out stay-at-home mums as hurting Australia's economy, reports The Daily Telegraph.
Housewives are the country's 'greatest untapped potential' according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) who claim there are 'potentially large losses to the economy when women stay at home or work short part-time hours'.
Being paid for work was also found to be an important factor for a mother's happiness, according to the employment study.
Women deciding to stay at home to look after their family is hurting Australia's economy, a study by OECD claims (stock image)
But Parenthood executive director Jo Briskey says some women are unable to go into full-time employment as they can't afford childcare.
But she added it's important women have the choice.
'Women need flexible work arrangements and a supportive workplace that helps them meet their responsibilities at work and home,' she told the Daily Telegraph.
'If they want to stay home it's an incredibly important job looking after kids — not just for the family but to build society.'
The employment study found women were better educated than their male counterparts with over half of 25-34 year olds with a degree, while only 43 per cent of men have one.
Research also showed around half of single mothers were in paid work, while 45 per cent of mother in a relationship worked part-time jobs.
